This movie was a gorgeous exploration of the isolation and desperation in human suffering. Aronofsky's movies frequently revolve around these themes, and this is one of his easiest to absorb and one of his best. Due to a lot of high profile backlash against Brendon Fraser playing the role of a morbidly obese man rather than a real obese person being cast in the role, I was prepared to be potentially offended, but upon seeing the movie I was actually astonished that anyone would cast fault upon such a sincere and loving portray as Fraser offered. This is an exceedingly sensitive and beautiful acting, and I actually wonder if the detractors even saw the film, or just reacted in unthinking "wokeness" to word of its existence. This is as good as anything  released by a major studio in the last 10 years, which might be called the Marvel and Reboot Era. It's no longer even a debate that Hollywood has for years sacrificed its relevance and vitality on a pyre of lowest-common-denominator audience pandering, and I had begun to wonder, I think fairly, if movies of real quality and meaning would ever be made again. Aronofsky's career nicely tracks the rise and fall of the indie cinema over the past 30 years, beginning with the supremely underground surprise pop hit of Pi, made of $60k in 1998, which grossed $3 million. It was then closely followed by a wave of big studio support which resulted in Requiem for a Dream two years later, made for $4.5M and distributed by Artisan Entertainment two years later, which succeeded in expanding his range of audience appeal without sacrificing a drop of artistic cred. The Whale makes a strong case for Aronofsky as one of the very few filmmakers working today with nearly the same artistic integrity as was regularly present in the mid to late 90's indie wave. Is it every bit as daring and bold as Requiem, Black Swan, or Pi? My sense is that those movies had more grit to them, they had a greater capacity to disturb, that The Whale is perhaps more smoothed-out, less alienating, and more ready for a broader audience. This does not really bother me, although I can understand why indie cool kids might consider it "soft" by comparison, even if it will still prove too challenging for many viewers. I'll disclose that I feel this sort of film student thinking is much ado about nothing. But whatever one's position on the position of grit in relation to authenticity, in terms of the ability to speak and make meaning from film, The Whale is surely the equal of Aronofsky's best work. Really a surprising, moving, and ultimately uplifting movie that broadens our capacity to be human and boldly confirms that great film is not dead.

No question Brendan Fraser's performance as the 'whale' is outstanding - and does a lot to help the average person put aside their disgust for long-vehicle obesity, but as a drama, I found it littered with cliches. The young adult child who is still spinning in a loop of anger that her dad abandoned her for his lover when she was eight. Foaming at the mouth with self-pity. The angry ex, who turned to drink when she discovered her husband was bi-sexual. The exasperated nurse who scolds, then cries, scolds then cries. And here we go again with another teacher, who just wants his students to break out in some way and be 'honest' - be honest and the world will open up to them, he tells them. Haven't we had enough of this sort of thing in Good Will Hunting and other, lesser movies? 

The redemptive angle was also far too on-the-nose, what with this doubting young man who appears out of nowhere like a doubting angel claiming he wants to 'save' Charlie. It's almost hilarious, but where's the irony? And then the ending, with Charlie making these elephantine, yet triumphant steps towards his daughter hanging by the open doorway, launches us into opera, an almost narcotic experience, which, admittedly, is perhaps not surprising when you remember director Aronofsky's brilliant early film, Requiem For A Dream, that takes us inside the heads of heroin addicts for 90 minutes or so. 

I enjoyed The Whale, for sure, even as it made me nearly gag at times, (Charlie stuffing his face with pizza, for instance), but this was an opportunity to say something more about a health system and a culture that allows people to gorge themselves for so long they can't even bend over to pick up something they dropped on the floor. And it was a missed opportunity, to my mind. Too many moments of sappy tears and raised voices, not enough grit and irony.

The film is all about Moby Dick (another title for Moby Dick is The Whale) and Ellie's interpretation of it. The movie starts off with Thomas reading the essay and it saying "and I felt saddest of all when I read the boring chapters that were only descriptions of whales, because I knew that the author was just trying to save us from his own sad story, just for a little while." Which is a bit of a foreshadowing of the the rest of the film. But the film is about Thomas being Captain Ahab trying to kill the whale (save Charlie from damnation) and Charlie is Moby Dick. But because Charlie is so fat we of course associate him with Moby Dick but Charlie is also Captain Ahab and he tries to kill his whale (get to know Ellie). Ellie is also Captain Ahab as she literally wishes Charlie would die just as Ahab wishes Moby Dick would die. The saddest and boring chapters would be only a description of Charlie, him by himself and him eating himself to death, and Thomas, Liz and Ellie comes in to save you from the sad story for a while. At one point Ellie even tells Thomas he finally feels he's interesting once she gives him the opportunity to tell his story, just like Charlie told her if you give reading a chance he felt she would actually like it, just like he feels if Ellie gives people a chance she could actually like them. Captain Ahab only sees Moby Dick as a whale he wants to kill and forgets animals can have feelings and be complex characters that would be better off left alone, just like Thomas forgets Charlie is an older man who has lived a long life and has his own story, in the end Thomas admits he finds him disgusting and just wants to save him for his own benefit and doesn't have Charlie's best interest in mind, seeing him as just an animal, just a whale. Ellie also sees Charlie as disgusting as just an animal but not because of his weight but because he left her for someone else. But when Charlie tells Ellie about why he left, she remembers he's human and not Moby Dick not just a whale but a human with feelings. Charlie tells Thomas he's already read his book which refers to the Bible but also Moby Dick and he feels that Ellie's essay of her interpretation of Moby Dick is the best writing he's ever read because it's just so honest. Ellie then confronts Thomas, just as she confronts Captain Ahab with her essay, she is honest with Ahab and with Thomas and by doing so releases Thomas from his own feeling he can't go home without killing the whale. Thomas then becomes Ishmael just as Ellie and Charlie become Queequeg, since Thomas and Ellie no longer see Charlie as an animal he is no longer Moby Dick, and becomes a human character. Just as Ishmael in Moby Dick is someone who sees Queequeg at the beginning of the story as basically a heathen or an animal, then by the end of the story sees them as the most caring and kind people they've ever know, just as he saw Charlie as someone who is disgusting and Ellie as a problem child but there is so much more to them than meets the eye. Charlie always sees Ellie as Queequeg, a caring person, even when her mom or Thomas didn't see her that way because Charlie always sees the best in people. In the end Ellie's writing released Thomas to go home, her writing releases Charlie as well, the ending she reads her essay and says "This book made me think about my own life, and then it made me feel glad for my--" this is left for interpretation of the viewer, whether she says she is glad for "myself" would make Charlie happy that she does love herself, or whether she says she is glad for her "dad" either way he knows he did something right with his life, and that's all he wanted.

Also I saw some people write that if you movies that are just in one room then you'll like this movie, well Moby Dick is just set in one place also, the sea. There is also a point where Ishmael finally sees Captain Ahab who was locked in his quarters and is scared of him, like when Dan finally sees Charlie.

Well, I can see why the critics don't like it. They don't like movies that criticize religion, and Aronofsky does that plenty. The film seems typical of Aronofsky. Very classic Aronofsky ending. I wouldn't say it's as gross as others seem to think, but it is pretty loud on the bickering side, and his daughter is especially difficult to listen to. There's no deeper meaning to this than say Mother, another film criticizing religion and taking the all too obvious path of saying the same ol things at the enormous cost of film production. Frankly, I am disappointed so many people choose to address this subject with film as some flimsy art form cover up for their disliking of an ancient practice that has more than sunk itself with its own actions. But yet, here we are again. Another film pointing out our own faults and personal salvation or ruin. Highlighting the faults and idiocy of religion while also reflecting on its surface value for those who need it. The whole existence of the daughter in the film is a reflection of that. We're all her. But we don't have to be... It's not my thing, but it is well done. I don't particularly suggest watching it, but if you are one of those people who like obvious messages convolutedly buried in grim films, then this is probably right up your alley. If that's not you, you should probably ignore this one. And don't read the comments. You'll just get angry.

Impressively performed by Brendan Frasier. The depth, pacing, score, and editing worked very well to tell a story that felt great to get behind. Unfortunately, it includes an ingredient that is both tasteless and (appearently) non negotiable in Hollywood culture these days. It includes an element of Christianity that starts off innocent, even convincing, only to subvert you by having the message of the movie come against it in order to villainize it. 
Interestingly in this film, it took away from the power it could have otherwise had the potential to have. Not only did they miss an opportunity for him to find peace with God as part of his redemption, but Charlie held onto his bitterness toward him until the end, and in turn, diminishing the message of his story. Additionally, the characters spend so much runtime fighting God, despite how they feel about him, that you can feel the precious hours slipping away from Charlie's life, while they alL continue to indulge in their contempt. They try to give the characters some context by giving them an in depth history with the church, but these characters' attitudes for people who have "read every pamphlet" or the entire Bible multiple times are outlying at best.
In other words, the shoehorned anti-christian message is inaccurate, unecessary, and the reason why this film was good, but not great, and certainly not a masterpiece.
...Which is a shame, because other than that, all the other elements, the characters, the acting, writing, editing, pacing, score, are all excellent.

This movie was truly a rollercoaster that kept spiraling downwards, in the best of ways.  I was shocked by the state that Charlie was in and every single character was easy to empathize with.  This movie made me cry multiple times because I knew what would happen, but it was the painful journey that was most important.  This movie is a wonderful tragedy about the sickness of food addiction and it left me speechless throughout.  The writing was phenomenal and the acting made everything realistic.  With how common obesity is in America, it was easy to relate to in some way, and I think everyone will think "I know someone whose obese," when they see this film.  I think this was one of the best movies I've seen this year because it made me feel and care about what was happening.  Now, the reason I gave this film 4.5 stars is because there was one incredibly important moment that quite literally shut my waterworks down.  This was the very ending.  Charlie had just succeeding in reconnecting with his daughter and helping her realize just how precious she is, all while on the verge of death and walking without help for the first time in a long time.  The music swells, the moment intensifies as Ellie and Charlie stare at each other, and right when I'm about to cry, his feet lift from the ground in a symbolic death and salvation from his tragic life.  Charlie ends up on the beach, in the moment he loves so much, in heaven.  And then the movie ends.  It is when the spiritualistic death took place, where he is literally lifted from the ground, that I stopped crying.  The movie has been so real, so solid, so down to Earth, that it felt supernatural and preachy when Charlie goes to heaven.  If the music cut and his heart went flat or he exhaled his last breath and the screen went white with credits, I would have started sobbing.  Charlie said he didn't want there to be an afterlife, he stated his opinions over and over again, so in a way, the film goes against his characters wishes by giving him the after life.  And if the moment at the beach isn't his heaven, but him reliving his life as it flashes over his eyes, then that would be too repetitive.  After all, the entire movie is spent exploring his life, the choices he's made, and how he lives in his last few days.  This should have ended tragically, very much like how Shakespeare ends his tragedies.  It should have been devastating to see or hear Charlie die, but instead, it seemed the producers wanted to give him a happy ending.  When a story is purely tragic, I do not want to see a happy ending.  I want the bittersweet ending of him finally making amends for his mistakes only to die a moment later, unable to ever see how his daughter will grow or see her smile.  I do not think he ever saw her smile as a teenager.  And that would have added another layer to his tragic life and death.

After watching "The Whale" my first thought was how in the hell was this not the best picture of the year? This was a marvelous, emotionally-devastating film with the Oscar-winning performance of Brendan Fraser, but also the no-less-powerful performances of Hong Chau as Liz and Samantha Morton as Mary. This movie delivers a one-two-punch of guilt and regret, displaying the devastating effects on people.

I need to schedule a viewing of "Everything Everywhere All at Once" as soon as possible in order to determine, in my own mind, whether or not an injustice has been done.
People are incapable of not caring. People are amazing. Best picture a long time ago.

There's only one flaw with this movie (Charlie could not have possibly known the last second/instant he was alive and be able to time it perfectly with that moment with his daughter in the end). Other than that, ignore every single bad review for this movie, they miss the entire point and don't see this masterpiece for what it truly is. Brendan Fraser acts so well (along with the entire supporting cast) and the emotional drama and character archs from everyone in the movie are spectacles. It sends a profoundly powerful message and I think that this is the kind of movie that needs to exist, especially for individuals who have a hard time finding their place in life or who struggle from trauma. I liked that this movie took a big risk casting a non-obese person as an obese person. It still worked and some of the people who criticize the production for that never even checked out the movie to begin with or gave it a chance! It is so much more than an actor who portrays someone struggling with obesity, but instead struggling with the legacy of his turbulent and draining life in his final days, and what an incredible and original direction the movie went in with that! I liked this even better than Requiem for a Dream!

The viewer watches him spiral hopeless to help him, only able to observe as he eats himself to death and this helplessness can be fustrating for some who view Charlie's problem as an easy fix - stopping eating. I think the movie was a depressing masterpiece and i won't be forgetting it any time soon.

A man floundering in his own failure in life finally sees some white as everything else is layered in greys. The depictions of depression and self isolation are honest and without derision, and great emphasis is placed on the notions that human beings are as flawed as they are fantastic; that despite our best intentions, sometimes we do more harm than good; and that a little kindness and a positive outlook can make a world of difference, even when things seem bleak.

Although it's clear to me that the other actors performed at their best, Fraser's performance turned what would have otherwise been a merely okay film into something dramatic and impactful. The plight of his character Charlie engenders sympathy, and while the depictions of the consequences of his eating disorder can be quite graphic, at no point does the film attempt to portray Charlie as anything less than human for suffering from it.

Overall, I would say that this movie is worth your time.

Pity, relief, repulsion, grief or just a lot of sadness: when you leave the theather after watching "The Whale", at least one of these feelings has hit your stomach and remains there until you go to sleep. It's difficult to talk about this film without mention the terrific interpretation of Charlie, an overweight and dying (over 250kg) online teacher, by Brendan Fraser (awarded at the Oscars with Adrien Morot, the head between his makeup), for the first time in years acting in a leading role poignant and challenging to bring on screen. His character becomes more and more disgusting frame after frame until the dreamlike last sceen, where the white explodes and swallows every other color, completely opposite to the opening one, where a progressive zoom in the black reveals the title and his face. Director Darren Aronofsky though doesn't limit the script to a documentary about a week in the life of a morbidly obese and explores his story since he left his family (his wife and his son, Ellie, when she was 8) for one of his student, Alan, which died short after in misterious circumstances. THE WHALE, written by Samuel D. With only days left to live, the main focus of the movie sees Charlie trying to make amends with his estranged, strong-willed teenage daughter, Ellie (Sadie Sink). Fraser gives an emotionally riveting performance that carries the film. Also very good in her supporting role as Charlie's friend and caretaker, Liz is actress Hong Chau ("Driveways"). THE WHALE is a great comeback achievement from Brendan Fraser, his Charlie will pull at your heartstrings.

Brendan Fraser delivers a true masterpiece performance that tugs the heart strings on more than one occasion. The protagonist of this story is Charlie, a dangerously overweight individual who has suffered in isolation from the world after a tragic loss of the love of his life.
While attempting to be a bright light to those around him and make up for lost time with his estranged daughter, Charlie ignores his own health concerns.
We follow an impactful journey that leads us to an extremely dark place in the mind of someone who is truly wrestling with demons that many of us could not understand, an obesity that lies in self hatred and punishment as well as a way to cope with the pains of his past. Sadie Sink one could say is the antagonist of this story, Her Character Ellie gives a very dark reminder of the sins of Charlie's past and shows the true pain caused and an everlasting effect that his choices made. A confused and resentful character who appears throughout the story to have a deep rooted hatred for her father and who wants to torment him for abandoning her as a young child. Ellie is a very misunderstood teenager who is in her own way crying out to be rescued from herself and it appears that her father may be the only key to this. 
A movie that is shadowed in pity, anger, confusion yet somehow delivers a truly peaceful ending that allows a sense of completion to Charlie's initial goal. 
The whale is one that should be experienced, however tragic and confronting it may be.

I had not seen any reviews before watching this, and after watching the film and reading some very conflicting views on the film. I empathise with those responsible for Brendan Frasers Oscar nomination as I felt his acting was outstanding throughout. The characters in the film revolve Charlie, who is played by Brendan, and introduces 5 other characters who revolve around his story. I wouldn't say Brendan exactly carried the performance though as the whole cast were top notch. However, the film has received some negative feedback, and this may be the reason this film has not acquired the rotten tomatoes score one would assume it deserves. That is because it touches on the 'stigmatising reflection of thin peoples assumptions of fat bodies'. I don't buy into this as a criticism myself. I would agree that the film was emotionally provoking and made me feel uncomfortable or at at least uneasy at times. However, I do not think that the film was shallow in this sense. It is a fictional character, with a fictional storyline and with a over-fantasised and extremely animated displays of Charlies resignation in self-help and abandonment of aspirations as a consequence of his life choices and circumstances. I would say that if you are genuinely getting offended by this film and the topic therein then I would suggest creating a masterpiece like this one, exercise your own freedom of expression by shining a light on the issues, systematic or otherwise inferred in the criticisms. The film is supposed to make you feel uncomfortable, invite you to empathise, detest and sympathise for the characters. It's cinema, and cinema at its finest, the choice of how you respond to the movie will be personal and individual and I think that's what makes it so great. No one will watch this film and take away the same message as the person watching it with you. that's the point of it. It's a must see. Enjoy it.

The feature film shows the daily life of a writing/English teacher living in prison due to severe obesity who tries to reconcile with his teenage daughter in a single chance of redemption.

A Baleia is an adaptation of a play, I believe that is why people enter and leave the scene as if they were on a theater stage for everyone to connect with Charlie, right at the beginning of the project we are presented with our protagonist's routine, and issues controversies are already shown here regarding Charlie's health, how his self-esteem and sexuality are presented, the critics get heavy trying to accuse the director of portraying the character as if he were a circus character, however, the Obesity Action Coalition (OAC) disagreed and told Franser to keep doing what he's doing.

The beauty of this film is the study of human complexity of hurt people, hurting people as well as the pursuit of honesty towards one another. The tight cast of characters can be evaluated under a microscope where each line of dialogue can be reviewed to distinguish its deeper meaning. Fraser is particularly excellent in his role. The film struggles however with its lack of subtlety- offering a fairly predictable and coerced storyline and a flair for the dramatic, especially on Charlie's obesity. Charlie's obesity is a prominent component to the imagery of the film, but does not contribute much to the underlying message. The film tries to tackle too many tough topics (eating disorders, broken parent-child relationships, religion and homosexuality) while not fleshing them all out. Also, the films overt desire for drama (akin to a soap opera at times, and especially Sink's role) takes away from some of these deeper topics under the surface - not allowing the viewer to think critically of all viewpoints. The human condition is preposterous to behold - but the Whale tries to feed it to us on single-view, silver spoon.

Hold onto your blubber, folks, because "The Whale" is a heart-wrenching journey that will leave you feeling like a beached sea creature. With characters as complex and knotty as an old fishing net, this film will envelop you in a world of emotional drama that rarely strays from its stage origins. But don't be fooled by the lack of scenery changes, because the performances are outstanding, especially Brendan Fraser's portrayal of Charlie. He brings a sincerity to the role that is both open and gentle, and will leave you rooting for him despite his flaws.

Director Darren Aronofsky's obsession with the grotesque is alive and well in this film, but he manages to skirt the edge of exploitation and instead presents us with a splayed-open tragedy that is weirdly romantic. The film's rawness and wall-to-wall woe will leave you devastated, but also moved and practicing sympathy and forgiveness. And while the film doesn't add up to much in the end, the performances are top-notch, especially when Fraser, Chau, and Sink verbally bounce off of each other. So grab your tissues and dive into "The Whale," a film that will level you with the rawness of human sadness.

I appreciate the realism of this movie. Charlie's health looms heavy on the lives of even those who don't know him but should encounter the gravity of his existence (take or leave the pun). But through this very encumbered life, one might expect Charlie to be more humiliated, more panicked, more called-to-action... but like many of life's mortal traps, that is not often the case. Early in the movie, it becomes obvious that Charlie has in a way transcended these feelings (not a healthy way). He has literally become numb to the sense of failure, worthlessness, loneliness, and desperation.
 
Don't get me wrong, Charlie understands these things. He thinks himself to be a failure... alone... desperate... worthless, etc... but he has found a way to turn all of this into just a general state of aloof shame. "Sorry" just rolls off his tongue, and he doesn't even have the energy to resent people's disgust or pity anymore. Almost like he is bored of the indignity he has become accustomed to.
 
You can see it, particularly with his daughter. He's willing to bribe her with his life's accumulated wealth and without condition. He's simply a dead person who hasn't died yet... to himself.
 
As a person who has dealt with mental health issues in my family as well as drug problems, it's so refreshing to see a director take this candid angle... where the elephant in the room is not made the spectacle it should be. People expect problems of addiction to be reckless, but more times than not, it's very patient. It's mundane. It's a slow-moving train wreck... and once you find yourself there, you've been there for quite a while.
 
Any story of addiction is in and of itself an extremely potent and important cautionary tale, but to see Charlie's story expressed as a more tedious than emergent circumstance... that's a very important character point of view to truly understanding what is and has been going on in that room for the last decade.
 
This movie is built on that foundation... and that foundation is strong. I'll say it now, this movie will save lives. The humanity in this movie is palpable, relatable, and most importantly, actionable. While it is technically a work of fiction, it's simply more than that. It might not teach you your neighbor's circumstances, but it WILL teach you the shape of such circumstances.
 
Watch this movie with your family, friends, and neighbors in mind... and maybe yourself too. We're all in this thing together. Be good to yourself and others.

This movie is unsurprisingly good—for what reason I have yet to determine. What was surprising were the negative reviews from movie critics (like the one from my favorite critic's posthumous confab RogerEbert.com.) I garner that the themes of the movie are a cookie cutter assemblage of grief, mourning, depression, pain, self loathing, and moments of brilliance and wit that are in any good film. It's just that the poison of choice was a fat person—no morbidly obese person. 

I will admit that I gawked at the cabinet of curiosity. I did feel disgust as he choked on a piece of food he wolfed down. But that's not because of pity or disdain for the character it's actually a swig of self loathing because I could be there. I think those critics might feel guilt for all those feelings And at some levels self pity because we've ALL been in Charlie's place. Maybe food is not your drug of choice  but certainly overindulgence in social media, wine, fillers, surgery, or fill in the blank with your vice. 

The consequences of those vices are usually hidden—no one can look at you and tell you're addicted to social media or a budding alcoholic etc. With obesity, it's very much visual display of what can be the cause of an addiction to food. So it's funny or pitiful or cabinet-of-curiosity fun to look at. 

Whatever the consequent stereotypes to being obese is—they are real reactions people have to seeing a man not only eat himself to death but witnessing a downward spiral. Getting up and being soo big that you knock over stuff is sad and comically embarrassing. It's the reason why "Yo mama so fat" jokes exist. It's an insult to be called fat. That's real cultural phenomenon that happens in America. The portrayal of fat shaming—however cruel it may be in this film is a real thing that happens in society. Another movie based on a play, which is set entirely in the small apartment of our main character, Charlie.

Charlie is severely overweight but refuses medical care, and we learn through his only friend Liz who is a nurse that he will die in a few days from congestive heart failure if he does not seek medical attention. With this knowledge, Charlie decides to spend his last few days getting to know his estranged 17-year-old daughter. During this time, he's also visited by a young missionary from a local evangelical, end-times focused church who wants to lead him to salvation.

Liz is accustomed to being Charlie's only visitor and does not want guests coming by while Charlie is in this fragile state. Over the few days, the missionary grows in his belief that God led him to Charlie, and Charlie doubles down on his desire to reconcile with his daughter, offering her money and asking her to share her thoughts and be honest with him so that he can know her.

There are no heroes in this movie. Liz is overbearing and sometimes enabling to Charlie. Charlie's daughter Ellie is mean and full of fury. Her own mom calls her "evil". His ex-wife is a bitter alcoholic. The missionary is a liar. Charlie abandoned his family and deals with his pain through self-harm and self-pity.

But that's kind of the point. All of these people are broken and imperfect. They are all human. Like it or not, they all need to be saved.

But as Liz points out, you can't save another person, not really.

Charlie knows he can't save himself, but he's on a quest to find redemption before he dies, and it's all tied up in his daughter. He wants her to know she is special, that she can care about other people and be cared for - a message that's tough for her to hear from a dad who abandoned her and closed himself off from the world. He tries nonetheless, and there's something brave about that.

The movie grapples with faith in a way that provides a lot of theories and no answers, but feels incredibly sincere, something that's tough to do well onscreen.

Charlie is a complex character, a very human character, and Brendan Fraser will likely win an Oscar for embodying these contradictions so well. Sadie Sink gives a performance wise beyond her years and Hong Chau (who seems to be in everything these days) gives us another performance of strong, quiet toughness.

The script is awfully heavy-handed and that's a nightmare for a film that deals with not only family dynamics but religious belief, plus all the exposition makes it feel clunky. Subtlety is not a word that this filmmaker has ever heard in his life, and the 'revelations' that the protagonist undergoes as well as the ridiculously over-the-top behaviour of Sadie Sink's Ellie are a testament to that. The Whale is an epic saga of grief and redemption that demands to be seen by the whole world immediately. This film is one of the most heart-melting and rewarding movies I have ever seen. There's dramatic character development, stimulative dialogue and phenomenal performances. The cast, especially Brendan Fraser, took the film's inspiring synopsis and made it better, if not emotional, on so many levels. Fraser returns to the screen with a big bang in a career-best performance; it's great to see him back. As much as I love this film, I did run into its imperfections. No film is perfect though, right? The only conflict I came across with The Whale was finding out how Ellie's character is extremely unlikable, it's mildly exhausting. Usually, I try to avoid giving attention to my least favorite characters, but Ellie really stood out to me. It seems that everything she does is toxic, manipulative and vastly disrespectful, to the point where it's life-threatening. Ellie has a devastating, yet very strong impact on other characters and blackmails them to be rebellious as her. For instance, Ellie dares a devoted young Christian, Thomas, to take a hit of her pot and says that she'll call 911 and tell the cops that he raped her if he did not comply. We find out shortly after that she was "joking". Extremely disgusting and unprofessional. Ellie also takes pictures of her father and cyberbullies him on Facebook, which turns out she does that to the vast majority of the characters in the film. Did I mention she drugs her father too? It seems that all the other characters mature, but she just stays where she is. I honestly don't understand why Charlie gives her the chance. Look, I love Sadie Sink as an actress, but seeing her, or any other actress follow the same script Ellie did, I would find them annoying. But despite my criticism, this unique movie shows rare compassion, and long-lasting friendships that are in the sequence of healing. I love how Darren Aronofsky managed to blend in Christianity too. The ending melted my heart and made my eyes water. The Whale is a must-watch and believe me, the hype about it is real. My personal rating: 9/10

I'd been wanting to see The Whale ever since it was announced. It was exciting to see Brandan Fraser making a big return, and in a dramatic film too. Plus, I'm a big fan of Darren Aronofsky, and so I was happy to see him back too. The film's play roots are evident, from the dialogue and character driven story, to the limited locations, to the staging of most of the scenes and lack of flashy editing or effects. It's a pretty simple story about a father trying to reconnect with his estranged daughter, with the twist being that the father weighs several hundred pounds and is borderline immobile. Fraser brings a lot of humanity and believability to the role, and its smart that his weight isn't what defines him, he has an actual personality. With such a small cast of characters, its easier to make everyone feel 3 dimensional, and that's what the movie does, with the exception of the daughter character. The ways she's written and played is so over the top nasty and spiteful, and with virtually no redeeming features, that'll you'll grow tired of her very quickly. It's such a shame that this individual is so key to the central conflict, because we have to endure her rants, insults, abuse and constant belittlement to the point that Charlie's adoration of her, even by the standards of someone starved for company and compassion, makes no sense, and the film becomes a drag whenever she's onscreen. It's a hugely melodramatic film, with the 3rd act feeling like one long crying scene, but if you're wrapped up in Fraser performance and character you'll likely be shedding tears yourself when the credits roll. It's another well-crafted and highly divisive film from Aronofsky, a man who's made a living enthralling and shocking his audience, and while I can't see myself watching it again, the story and characters make one watch more than worth your time.

Brendan Fraser delivers a triumphant comeback performance in Darren Aronofsky's most recent feature "The Whale". Samuel D. Hunter adapts his own award-winning play for the big screen, telling a devastating story about one man's last shot at redemption. Aronofsky's decade-long quest to get the film made has finally come to fruition in the form of a haunting drama that takes place entirely in one apartment in Idaho during the 2016 U.S. election.

Charlie (Brendan Fraser) is a reclusive college professor who teaches online writing classes from the comfort of his couch and behind the façade of a broken laptop camera. He has no friends, apart from his nurse Liz (Hong Chau), and the only visitors he gets are a pizza delivery guy and a Mormon missionary called Thomas (Ty Simpkins). Charlie's obesity is causing detrimental damage to his health and his steadfast refusal to go to the hospital doesn't help, but when Liz tells him he's at risk of heart failure, the grave reality of his situation dawns on Charlie. With only weeks, if not days left, he decides to attempt to reconnect with his daughter Ellie (Sadie Sink).

"The Whale" is fuelled by sensational turns from the entire cast, but Brendan Fraser's portrayal of Charlie stands out as one of the best performances of 2022. Fraser captures heart-breaking emotion in his performance, effortlessly bringing Charlie's vulnerability to the screen. The various prosthetic pieces Fraser donned to transform into Charlie elevated his performance to another level, balancing impactful emotion with an impressive physical performance also. The film allows Fraser to deliver the best performance of his career that will hopefully garner the actor his first Oscar nomination. "Stranger Things" star Sadie Sink appears alongside Fraser taking on the role of Ellie, Charlie's estranged teenage daughter. Sink delivers a powerful performance that immediately lets audiences know just how spiteful the 17-year-old highschooler can be, spitting venomous words taken straight from the pages of Hunter's play. Hong Chau adds to her already impressive year, appearing in Kelly Reichardt's "Showing Up" and Mark Mylod's "The Menu", delivering a stunning performance, shining in every scene she's in.

"The Whale" is a stellar adaptation of Hunter's play, it flawlessly brings the characters and the story to the screen through a layered, thematic screenplay that forms the foundation for an impactful drama. The film balances a handful of emotions including guilt, shame, and anger, and themes like grief and religion. "Insidious" star Ty Simpkins, through a strong performance, embodies the film's themes of religion by portraying a Mormon missionary who tries to convert Charlie to Mormonism in order to ‘save him', but as the film progresses it's revealed that both Charlie and Liz already have a connection to the religion, bringing up painful memories and opening old wounds. The film also weaves in references to the Herman Melville's novel "Moby Dick" and other marine-themed components including the recurring sound of waves which was taken directly from Hunter's play.

Oscar-nominee and long-time Aronofsky collaborator Matthew Libatique once again gets to show off his immense talent for creating stunning visuals. Libatique uses the fact that the film takes place entirely in one location (Charlie's apartment), except for one scene at the start, to craft stunning visuals that emphasises the isolation Charlie feels because he's unable to leave his apartment. This puts the audience in his shoes, allowing them to feel the same isolation he does, only seeing other people when they come to visit. Libatique's work compliments the other technical aspects of the film, from Andrew Weisblum's editing to the remarkaPble special effects makeup, courtesy of Adrien Morot ("Barney's Version"), that reinforces Fraser's performance. Composer Rob Simonsen ("Foxcatcher") produces a haunting score that excellently matches the film's empathy and aching sadness.

"The Whale" is a film lead by an outstanding performance from Brendan Fraser and is bolstered by marvellous supporting turns from Sadie Sink, Hong Chau and Ty Simpkins. Darren Aronofsky directs a sensational adaptation of Samuel D. Hunter's play, and fingers crossed he directs Fraser to a very well-deserved Oscar nomination. This is by far one of 2022's most powerful films, full to the brim with gut-wrenching emotion that will leave you teary eyed. "The Whale" sticks with you long after the credits have rolled, from the performances (especially Fraser's and Sink's) to the complex themes covered throughout the neat two-hour runtime.

Couple of comments: this is the latest from director Darren Aronofsky (Requiem For a Dream", "The Wrestler"). Here he brings the theater play of the same name by Samuel Hunter to the big screen. The movie doesn't betray its theater roots and in fact the entire film plays out in Charlie's apartment. There are a lot of heavy duty discussions in this film, a sizeable portion on religion, of all things. The cast is outstanding, including Hong Chau (as Liz) and. Sadie Sink (as Ellie). But the film will be mostly remembered for the towering performance by Brandon Fraser as the obese Charlie. I read that it took 4 hours each day to get the prosthetics arranged. Of course none of this would've mattered if it weren't for the high quality script by Samuel Hunter (who also wrote the stage play). In all, I didn't know how I would react to this film, obvious Oscar-baiting material. Turns out this is solid film starring a staggering performance by Fraser. He rightly got a Best Actor Oscar nod and he is probably a strong favorite to win it. Hollywood just loves a good comeback story like this one,

What happens when a fictional character becomes that human reincarnation of a someone whose proportions resemble that of a WHALE. There is something that doesn't quite hit the mark in THE WHALE, but it is still a worthwhile movie to watch. Charlie, a reclusive English teacher suffering from severe obesity, attempts to reconnect with his estranged teenage daughter in a desperate bid for redemption. With his time running out and his health failing, Charlie must fight his way through his self-imposed isolation and the walls he's built up around him to find the courage to open up to his daughter and to find a way to make amends.

Brendan Fraser, who plays Charlie, does an incredible job of conveying the complex emotions and struggles of being overweight. His performance is convincing and heartbreaking as he battles his physical limitations while attempting to build a bridge between himself and his daughter. Fraser's portrayal of Charlie is believable, allowing us to empathise with him despite his flaws.

THE WHALE also features impressive performances from young actor Sadie Sink (Charlie's daughter, Ellie) and Hong Chau (Liz, Charlie's best and only friend). Sink does an excellent job of portraying the tension between Ellie and her father, as well as conveying the emotions of an adolescent trying to cope with an absent parent. Chau is also excellent in her role, providing much-needed comedic relief while still being able to convey genuine emotion and concern for Charlie.

THE WHALE occurs almost entirely in Charlie's apartment. This setting allows the film to focus on the personal drama between Charlie and Ellie and provides a claustrophobic atmosphere that enhances the sense of desperation and isolation. Director Darren Aronofsky uses this limited space to significant effect, creating an intimate portrait of two people struggling with their issues while trying to bridge the gap between them.

The cinematography in THE WHALE is also noteworthy. The camera often lingers on Fraser's face or body for extended periods, allowing us to fully appreciate the physical and emotional toll that Charlie's condition has taken on him.

Unfortunately, THE WHALE suffers a few shortcomings that prevent it from being genuinely great. The pacing is sometimes slow, with some scenes dragging on longer than necessary. The film also lacks much plot development or character growth, leaving some characters feeling one-dimensional and underdeveloped. It also seems, at times, to have the feel of a stage production rather than a fully-fledged cinematic experience.

Despite these issues, THE WHALE is an emotionally resonant film worth watching for its performances alone. It may not be perfect, but it is a thought-provoking and poignant film that will leave you with much to ponder.

I kid you not, this is one of the most powerful, raw and emotional performances by Brendan Fraser, or anybody else for that matter,  that you're ever likely to see.   

His portrayal of Charly, the morbidly obese and reclusive English writing teacher who teaches his college students on the internet from his apartment that he's unable to leave, had me drawn to him, hook, line & sinker from the word go.  

The superlatives from the manner in which this story was told never end.   The poignant scenes where Charly speaks so calmly, eloquently and intelligently to his group of students, yet while all the students faces are shown on the internet zoom screen, a blank space (for the teacher) is all that the students see is so profound. They are completely unaware of the desperately sad, emotional,  lonely & grossly overweight figure behind the screen. until the last moments of the movie. 

There are scenes in this movie that will leave you emotionally wrecked as you can't help but be deeply moved by many of the heart-wrenching scenes as he valiantly tries to reconnect with the teenage  daughter he abandoned when she was just 8 yrs old. His daughter, Ellie, (played by Sadie Sink), is however full of hate and disgust for her father and she treats with with absolute distain.

And that stare … OMG, Charly reaches into the belly of the big screen with the saddest, loneliest, grief stricken and heartbroken expressive eyes that seriously will have you reaching for the tissues. You see the desperately torn man who through grief, love and loss of his male partner years before led him to spiral out of control and end up the in the grossly disturbing physical & mental state that the viewers see as he literally eats himself to death.  It is real, raw, heartbreaking and emotional as you see lives and relationships ruined as a result of Charly's despair.   It is something that I feel could so easily resonate with any other "regular" family. 

The binge eating scenes I tell you will shock and sadden you to your core and just wanna make you throw your arms around this mountain of a man as he devours everything in sight while googling congestive heart failure.

Brendan Fraser delivers a portrayal of a broken man full of regret, a prisoner in his own body who can't leave his apartment.  He shocks us and saddens us with his grossness, yet is also disarmingly graceful and full of sensitivity. 

This is a movie so disturbingly honest &  it will piece your spirit in very unexpected ways. It's not an easy watch, but a necessary one & I guarantee it will leave you changed. 

The whole movie is shot from his apartment, much like a stage play yet this in no way detracts. It is portrayed over a one week timetable in which Charly gets visits from other cast members including Thomas, a missionary who wants to save Charly's soul, his long-suffering carer (Liz) played by Hong Chau, his daughter Ellie & her embittered mother, Mary. 

A powerful, and very moving film that you MUST go & see.   I cannot recommend it highly enough.

In "The Whale," actor Brendan Fraser ("Crash," "The Mummy" series) is transformed by prosthetics into a character so morbidly obese that simply rising from a chair represents superhuman effort.  Director Darren Aronofsky ("The Wrestler," "Black Swan") confronts us with this spectacle, then dares us to look away.  Aronofsky also injects a few familiar elements into the proceedings – an anguished protagonist, surrealism and a general sense of melodrama.
In this chamber piece, Charlie (Fraser) has congestive heart failure.  He's literally eating himself to death.  In Idaho.  He's unable to leave his claustrophobic, poorly-lit apartment.  He spends his time teaching online classes in creative writing and receiving caretaker visits from Liz (a fantastic Hong Chau – "The Watchmen TV series).  Realizing that he is in his last days, Charlie makes a final effort to reconnect with his daughter Ellie (Sadie Sink – TV's "Stranger Things").  As they story unfolds, the moviegoer learns that Charlie abandoned Ellie when she was eight because he fell in love with a male student.  Unsurprisingly, Ellie has some anger and abandonment issues.
One of the fascinating elements of this film is Charlie's steadfast optimism.  When Ellie's mother describes her as evil, Charlie rises, metaphorically, to her defense.  It's an intended irony that Charlie is able to offer powerful grace and absolution (there are a fair number of theological themes here) to nearly everyone but himself.
Throughout, "The Whale" feels much more like a play than a movie.  It was originally a stage production, with playwright Samuel D. Hunter acting here as the screenwriter.  Some of the "action," dialogue and staging are never translated effectively to this different medium.  It becomes a distraction when the actors sometimes seem restricted to broad movements and loud voices, mannerisms that don't work well with Aronofsky's camera inches from their faces.
It's hard to know how to react honestly to Fraser's performance.  It's a long Hollywood tradition to respect, even revere, actors who go through dramatic physical transformations.  Think Christian Bale in "The Fighter," Charlize Theron in "Monster," Joaquin Phoenix in "The Joker," or most recently Glenn Close in "Hillbilly Elegy." Here, Fraser does a wonderful job of showing the humanity and humor of a character who could easily be singularly unappealing.  But I'm not sure it's worth the Oscar buzz generated by many professional critics.
Ultimately, "The Whale" is a study in inconsistency.  Its paradoxes can be summed up by one of the key scenes where Charlie earnestly applauds and encourages the members of his online class who have made the effort to reveal themselves by expressing their own hard-earned truths.  It's ironic that this exhortation comes from a character whose enormous bulk is clearly used to keep everyone away.

Making your central character flawed and unsympathetic is one thing, making him physically repugnant is a particularly bold and auspicious creative choice for playwright Samuel D. Hunter whose play he has himself adapted for Darren Aronofsky's new film. Charlie is a morbidly obese, sweaty and balding online English tutor who's so grief-stricken and ashamed, he never leaves his house and over the course of 5 days, the film charts the visits made by Hong Chau's nurse friend, Liz, Ty Simpkins' eager missionary, Thomas and Sadie Sink's angry daughter, Ellie, whom Charlie has abandoned years ago and is now trying to reconnect with. Manifesting his disgust for himself physically through his overeating and obesity, it requires an equally fearless actor to take on the role and a particularly ego-free Brendan Fraser, making his cinematic comeback after perfecting a similar role on Doom Patrol, literally disappears into the heavy and grotesque prosthetic suit to become Charlie in an affecting and incredibly nuanced and complex turn that makes him the man to beat comes this year's Oscars. Whilst this film is admittedly stagy and perhaps sentimental even, these criticisms pale into insignificance in the face of such a strong, moving and emotionally powerful screenplay that uses Melville's Moby Dick as a springboard to illustrate the state of mind of its main characters, not to mention also allusions to Charlie's physical size. Initially sketchy characters develop surprising depth and layers as they are gradually fleshed out and their backstories revealed, while Charlie searches for redemption with the erratic Ellie. This is that rare beast of a film where an intricately constructed screenplay meets a tremendous cast that delivers with aplomb, producing something that grabbed me immediately from the beginning and never let up until it arrives at its gloriously humane and empathetic conclusion.

I went into this movie expecting it to be a real tear jerker.  I was hoping this was one of those movies that was deeply impactful in a way that only truly great movies are.  I kinda wanted to be emotionally rocked.

But it didn't meet that mark. 

The movie was definitely intellectually interesting.  And it definitely created some emotions -- particularly really leaning into revulsion or disgust or sadness around Branden Frasier's character's condition.  

But I didn't feel strong emotions around the relationships.  Sadie Sink, the girl who plays the daughter, nearly steals the show at times with a really strong performance but then disappears from the plot for a little while.

Overall I would put this in the solidly good and maybe even very good category but not great.  And I'd put in a warning there are some scenes around his morbid obesity and his eating disorder that are hard to watch.

While there were other movies to see including a 3D Avatar, an action movie "The Plane", et. al., I chose this movie because I was looking forward to something that movies have forgotten about, dialogue. Besides the amazing acting of Fraser, all the rest did their part so well to create a drama that left me, at times, wondering where they were going with particular scenes. 

In one way, the movie adapted from an off-Broadway play, seemed at times, staying true to the nature of a play.

I won't get into all the stories that came together in that one apartment, that's opening the floor for debate, and no opinion is wrong. I loved it.

Something better happened for me. As a race, human beings are all about looks. If you see an obese person, that may be all you see, but that's not who we are supposed to be to one another. 

This movie went to the heart of Fraser's character, and let the audience see the struggle of obesity and the addiction to food. 

Perhaps some people will walk away with more than they bargained for, perhaps they will see people beyond flesh and bone, for what their soul is trying to say. Perhaps the jokes that we say out loud for a quick laugh will someday end.

Finally, when this movie ended, when the screen turned white and the credits rolled, no one, including myself, got up from their seats. We sat there, almost frozen. 

This is the type of film, although adapted from a play, is what we all need more of when we sit down to enjoy something on the big screen.

There's a lot that can be said about the performances of Brendan Fraser, Hong Chau, and Sadie Sink in The Whale. The film itself is done very well. Pace is slow, but it's a drama, it's meant to be fleshed out. It doesn't wow or thrill or inspire awe, but it does hit you square in the heart. Brendan gave his all to that role and you can see it from the very beginning. I couldn't help but want an after credit scene, something to let the audience know what happens with the characters next. The final hour of the film, give or take, is the most moving as the history behind each character is revealed. It's a touching story that makes you long for reconciliation. The sad truth of the film is this: dying is no fairytale. We want to think there's going to be a chance to make everything right before the end, that this mortal coil can somehow be made whole through forgiveness. It's a poor substitute. When all is said and done, no one goes with you when your time comes, and you likely won't know when that will be. There's no more goodbyes after that, no more second chances. All that's left is what you've left behind, and something that The Whale teaches us - which it teaches us several things - is that you shouldn't hide, shouldn't wait for those moments you've been wishing for or missing. Because a day will come that will be your last and all that's left will be the love you left behind. If you can, give all of the love you have. That's what people will want the most.

I came upon a fork in the road on this overcast winter Wednesday afternoon: sit and keep working or slip away for two hours and go see a movie.

The movie of most interest was "The Whale".

I had an idea of what I could probably expect from this movie: touching, sentimental, worthwhile, nothing too earth-shaking.

I was on the fence about whether to see it in theaters or wait until its release on some streaming service.

I decided to see it now, in theaters, to show my absolute support for Brendan Fraser. 

I had found out recently that Brendan had been unjustly blacklisted these past many years by the unconscionable, grotesque Hollywood elite. I readily admit that buying a ticket to a movie is not much of a "Fnck Yon" to that cowardly disgusting underbelly of predominantly white male movie makers who dominate this industry and destroy the lives and livelihoods of those who will not silently submit to their warped sociopathic perversions, but it was one small thing I could do today.

But I digress. "The Whale". Written by Samuel D. Hunter. Directed by Darren Aronofsky.  Staring Brendan Fraser, Sadie Sink, Hong Chau, Ty Simpkins, Samantha Morton, Sathya Sridharan, and Jacey Sink. 

This powerful movie wrote on the slate of my soul.

It is possible that I felt its power so completely because of the circumstances and experiences I lived through this past year.

But if you imagine you will see it one day, see it now in the theaters. I would further recommend seeing it alone in the middle of the day if that's a thing that can be arranged.

I won't say more. You decide.

Ever since I saw "A Bright New Boise" on stage in the basement theatre on Ludlow Avenue, I've been a fan of Samuel D. Hunter's work. As a playwright - and now as a screenwriter - he knows how to keep the action moving; he writes snappy and realistic dialogue. His characters are always well-rounded and exciting; they always have something to do and say that is meaningful and advances the story. And most of all, he is a master of telling a straightforward tale while using symbolism, metaphor, and insight to move the audience.

"The Whale" is another of Hunter's plays, and I've long been anticipating its release on film. I've been reading and hearing about how great Brendan Fraser is as "Charlie," the 600-pound protagonist, and I finally saw it this afternoon. This script - like "Boise" - examines faith, spirituality, and religion respectfully but honestly. Still, it allows for so much character work that the entire cast shines brightly.

Fraser is the star of the movie, of course, and is as natural as one could be in that much makeup and prosthetics. But equally convincing is Hong Chau as "Liz," Charlie's only friend, Sadie Sink ("Ellie," Charlie's estranged teenage daughter), Ty Simpkins ("Thomas," a young man on a Christian mission), and Samantha Morton ("Mary," Charlie's ex-wife.)

All of these characters' stories are peeled back like onions throughout the film, guided by the very patient hand of Darren Aronofsky. Aronofsky ("Black Swan," "The Wrestler") always guides the audience through a story without rushing while making sure the characters - and thus the actors - stay in the forefront. In this 117-minute piece, he explores the fascinating dynamics between best friends, ex-lovers, parents and children, not to mention humanity's relationship with God. It's really well done.

The friend who accompanied me did not particularly like the movie. And if one was to approach this from a straightforward movie-going experience, I could understand the disappointment. The characters are all flawed; however, none of them are unredeemable. And that's the beauty of Charlie - despite his miserable, lonely, and painful existence, he never loses sight of the light in the world and in others.

Who would have thought such a broken, depressing character could be a role model for us all? I think that's the beauty of "The Whale."

I'm not going to dive into the synopsis of the film because it is widely available online, and frankly, the film "shows" you the story so well that the brief synopsis wouldn't do the story any justice. I want to applaud every single actor who played roles in this movie. Though I'm sure some acting professors may find criticisms in each of their ability, I believe that they all poured their hearts out playing these characters, the characters who are all fully justified of their own positions. With the origin of the film being a stage play, the film does everything in its power to keep the story intact without feeling the need to show everything, which is difficult to come by in our modern society where everything is shown, rather than told.

The characters are symbolic to say the least. Even though Charlie (Brendan Fraser) and his obesity may seem like a fiction or a non-fiction, it ultimately does not matter. After all, obesity is simply one of the health outcomes that we witness in our lives. One could easily replace Charlie's obesity with something else and they would end up with the same results as far as the story goes. And Charlie's not the only character who carries this symbol. Not only is every character in this story symbolic, each one is absolutely justified AND self-righteous. It's an endless loop that the characters have entrapped themselves in and there is no room for escape. With the unconventional display ratio of the film (not the usual 16:9 ratio), it feels like watching a personal diary that's filled with self-deprecation, frustration, and sheer agony that is inside a tight box. It is a tough pill to swallow as an audience, but a necessary one as it tells the tale that everyone needs to listen and comprehend. The film is not preachy to motivate the audience members to be proactive, but rather simply feeds us different combinations of characters's stories and make us think. That is why I think it is completely pointless to finger at any flaws or imperfections as it only illustrates the humanity behind our perfect selfies and posts. 

After two hours of the film (and ugly-crying for an hour and 30 minutes of it), I started to think how I would describe this film through an analogy. Aesop's fable of the North Wind and the Sun encapsulates the totality of experience from watching The Whale: at the end of the day, it wasn't the powerful North Wind who led the individual to take off their cloak, but rather it was the calmly, yet intensely present Sun's ray. Instead of the fast dynamic of a storm, this film consistently kept on twisting our guts. It continued to linger with both of us long after the film was over, and dare I say that it will remain with us for a long time. Films like this are neither easy to watch, nor easy to come by. The ugliness of humanity shows up in many forms and shapes that we cannot ignore or escape from them. Maybe if we let go of our self-righteousness, and maybe if we stopped giving into the hubris that the characters in this film commit to, maybe, just maybe the potential of humanity might expand and shake the world a bit more. Salute to all the actors, the director, the writer, the creative professionals for bringing this film into our world!

Darren Aronofsky's "The Whale" is a monumental embodiment of the fixation that seems to have burned itself into the director's soul: the notion of frantically clinging to morsels of personal salvation while careening desperately towards a messy, self-imposed oblivion. Watching the film, I was struck by three predominating impressions: that the melodramatic story amounted to something between a heart-wrenching work of drama and an outrageously grotesque spectacle, that Brendan Fraser's soul-stirring performance might as well conclude this year's Oscar's ceremony prematurely with him simply being mailed the award, and that in the artistic battle between the realistic and the poetic, poetry sometimes has something more honest to say about human experience. While not a film for either the faint of heart or those who think that slice-of-life naturalism is the only ethical way to approach matters of controversy, it will surely be appreciated by those who relish strong performances and Aronofsky's penchant for passionate, unrestrained film-making.

THE WHALE – directed by Darren Aronofsky, written by Samuel D. Hunter (after his original play) with Brendan Fraser (Charlie), Sadie Sink (Ellie), Ty Simpkins (Thomas), Hong Chau (Liz)

There are several themes in THE WHALE: obesity, identity, same-gender relationships, abandonment, parenthood and writing – the honesty of writing. And all these interlocking subjects are contained in little more than one living room, where one orderly corner meets a chaotic one.

I have read from those who feel offended by Daren Aronofsky's depiction of 600 lbs. Charlie, who  needs a walker to be able to move, who perspires with profusion, who, far from enjoying food, is an addict of it, and whose swallowing of pizzas and potato chips and jam and anything he finds in the fridge, is an emotional response to pain. His partner, unable to survive the judgment and rejection of his father, a pastor,  keeps losing weight and ends up committing suicide. This is the start of Charlie's bulging, and I wonder if the beginning of this disease is not his desire to bring back his lover, to feed him through his own distorted body. But I find no cruelty from director Darren Aronofsky in his portrayal. Neither cruelty nor disrespect. 

Does that mean there is no cruelty in the film? Actually, cruelty is aplenty, and emanates from the judgement of others (not the director) and from Charlie himself, who left wife and child in favor of his male lover. And let's not read this as a condemnation of homosexuality; let's read this as a condemnation of abandonment.

One cruel character is Ellie, Charlie's teenage daughter, played brilliantly by Sadie Sink who, with the multiplicity  of contradicting emotions traveling through her glance in seconds, is the one who deserves an Oscar in this powerful cast. (While Brendar's Charlie is masterful, something must be said about the make-up artists who created obesity with such realism.)  It is within those glances that you see that Ellie's meanness is pain that she cannot always disguise when compassion and the need to get close to her father filter through. 

But the cruelest of all is Thomas who claims his need to help with the message of God, but who ends up being a weak hypocrite who stole money from the church, who condemns Charlie's way of life, his love for another man, his "disgusting" appearance, and is all too happy to return to his parents and his selfishness. Writer Samuel Hunter's choice of Thomas is both ironic and symbolic, for it represents everyman's conflict between his need to believe and the proof that God exists. The Thomas of the film sees God as a faraway king, not as a force living in every being, and particularly by Charlie who sees the positive in everything and his conflicted daughter as "amazing."

Right away, Hunter tells us that we must look beyond the realism of the film. There is that constant motif of Moby Dick, of the whale (persecuted or persecutor), and the reminder that within the abandoned body of Charlie there the beautiful mind of a teacher who likes to share, embodied here by the computer English glass he teaches, where the videos of all students come across the screen, and where his image is replaced by a dark space that he refuses to fill with his appearance. Only his voice comes out, a warm baritone, the spirit of what he is.

The choice of the unity of place, at times suffocating, at times a womb, is a gutsy one, as well as the few characters that manage to create an entire universe with humanity's essential topics and worries. At times, when the voices rise and become so dramatic, I tell myself, this is more appropriate for the stage. And when I read the credits, I do find out that THE WHALE is originally a play by Samuel Hunter that he adapted for the big screen. But I wish he had gone further for this is cinema, I wish he had toned down those exclamations that make the movie less a piece of art than it could be. Sometimes murmurs are more powerful than shouts; sometimes sonatas are more powerful than symphonies. So when I read critics mention the lack of subtlety, I agree. For this is a film that needs subtlety.

It's still a film to watch. For all its themes. For the importance of addressing the disease of obesity. For opening a little wider our minds and our compassion.

The Whale is a film based on the play of the same name. This was easily my most anticipated film this entire year. The return of Brendan Fraser and another Darren Aronofsky film meant I would be seated on day one. After months of anticipation, I can say that The Whale provided an emotionally draining experience with brilliant, Oscar-winning performances all around. Brendan Fraser is as good if not better than you'd expect, he is brilliant here and if he doesn't win that Oscar I think I'll be sick. Charlie is a complex character that with the wrong actor and or performance, could've gone in a completely different direction. I can see why this film sat in developmental hell for years, as they really needed to find the perfect actor for this to work. But luckily Fraser wins you over as Charlie and you root for him the whole way through. The effects done to bring his body and character to life are nothing short of incredible either, it never feels over the top or unreasonable. Sadie Sink as Ellie was also incredible, she is a character you despise due to her attitude, but her character is redeemed once you learn more about her sympathetic situation. That character runs such a big risk of ruining the film, but luckily Sadie Sinks's performance and a strong script keep her character in check. Throughout this film, we are restricted to Charlie's apartment. Only ever seeing the outside in flashbacks or when Charlie enters his porch. His daily routines are the same each day and we watch Charlie follow these activities throughout the week. This makes the film feel shockingly real and very claustrophobic, which is exactly what Aronofsky wanted here. Hong Chau as Charlie's friend and nurse, Liz had a tough task presented towards her. She has to love and hate Charlie all the same, as she is his friend but wants to push him to get better when he stays stubborn about his life choices. I would not be surprised if she grabbed a nomination for best supporting actress. Where this film falls short is Ty Simpkins character, Thomas. He's a missionary who wants to help Charlie, his entire arc felt really out of place and most if not all scenes that focus purely on him felt dragged out and uninteresting. While I understand and actually liked the themes presented with his character being introduced here, it felt like his character was unnecessary majority of the time. The Whale falls flat in other areas too, such as some pacing issues, and the fact that at times it almost feels too much like a play, especially early on. While that may sound like the most extreme nitpick it made the film's structure feel extremely off at points. I don't mind if films feel like stage plays but only if it doesn't misconstrue their structure. Even with that said, by the end of this film, it really ties together nicely and provides one of the best endings to any film this entire year. Flaws and all, The Whale is another fantastic Aronofsky film that has me constantly thinking about it hours later. Bring your tissues, because The Whale is profoundly sad, yet inspiring. Go get that Oscar Brendan.

Brendan Fraser delivers a triumphant comeback performance in Darren Aronofsky's most recent feature "The Whale". Samuel D. Hunter adapts his own award-winning play for the big screen, telling a devastating story about one man's last shot at redemption. Aronofsky's decade-long quest to get the film made has finally come to fruition in the form of a haunting drama that takes place entirely in one apartment in Idaho during the 2016 U.S. election. 

Charlie (Brendan Fraser) is a reclusive college professor who teaches online writing classes from the comfort of his couch and behind the façade of a broken laptop camera. He has no friends, apart from his nurse Liz (Hong Chau), and the only visitors he gets are a pizza delivery guy and a Mormon missionary called Thomas (Ty Simpkins). Charlie's obesity is causing detrimental damage to his health and his steadfast refusal to go to the hospital doesn't help, but when Liz tells him he's at risk of heart failure, the grave reality of his situation dawns on Charlie. With only weeks, if not days left, he decides to attempt to reconnect with his daughter Ellie (Sadie Sink). 

"The Whale" is fuelled by sensational turns from the entire cast, but Brendan Fraser's portrayal of Charlie stands out as one of the best performances of 2022. Fraser captures heart-breaking emotion in his performance, effortlessly bringing Charlie's vulnerability to the screen. The various prosthetic pieces Fraser donned to transform into Charlie elevated his performance to another level, balancing impactful emotion with an impressive physical performance also. The film allows Fraser to deliver the best performance of his career that will hopefully garner the actor his first Oscar nomination. "Stranger Things" star Sadie Sink appears alongside Fraser taking on the role of Ellie, Charlie's estranged teenage daughter. Sink delivers a powerful performance that immediately lets audiences know just how spiteful the 17-year-old highschooler can be, spitting venomous words taken straight from the pages of Hunter's play. Hong Chau adds to her already impressive year, appearing in Kelly Reichardt's "Showing Up" and Mark Mylod's "The Menu", delivering a stunning performance, shining in every scene she's in.

"The Whale" is a stellar adaptation of Hunter's play, it flawlessly brings the characters and the story to the screen through a layered, thematic screenplay that forms the foundation for an impactful drama. The film balances a handful of emotions including guilt, shame, and anger, and themes like grief and religion. "Insidious" star Ty Simpkins, through a strong performance, embodies the film's themes of religion by portraying a Mormon missionary who tries to convert Charlie to Mormonism in order to ‘save him', but as the film progresses it's revealed that both Charlie and Liz already have a connection to the religion, bringing up painful memories and opening old wounds. The film also weaves in references to the Herman Melville's novel "Moby Dick" and other marine-themed components including the recurring sound of waves which was taken directly from Hunter's play. 

Oscar-nominee and long-time Aronofsky collaborator Matthew Libatique once again gets to show off his immense talent for creating stunning visuals. Libatique uses the fact that the film takes place entirely in one location (Charlie's apartment), except for one scene at the start, to craft stunning visuals that emphasises the isolation Charlie feels because he's unable to leave his apartment. This puts the audience in his shoes, allowing them to feel the same isolation he does, only seeing other people when they come to visit. Libatique's work compliments the other technical aspects of the film, from Andrew Weisblum's editing to the remarkaPble special effects makeup, courtesy of Adrien Morot ("Barney's Version"), that reinforces Fraser's performance. Composer Rob Simonsen ("Foxcatcher") produces a haunting score that excellently matches the film's empathy and aching sadness. 

"The Whale" is a film lead by an outstanding performance from Brendan Fraser and is bolstered by marvellous supporting turns from Sadie Sink, Hong Chau and Ty Simpkins. Darren Aronofsky directs a sensational adaptation of Samuel D. Hunter's play, and fingers crossed he directs Fraser to a very well-deserved Oscar nomination. This is by far one of 2022's most powerful films, full to the brim with gut-wrenching emotion that will leave you teary eyed. "The Whale" sticks with you long after the credits have rolled, from the performances (especially Fraser's and Sink's) to the complex themes covered throughout the neat two-hour runtime.

It's not just the performance from Brenden Fraser. This is the highest level of achievement of visual arts from a true film auteur and master of craft. It's a raw, heart-wrenching tale of familial drama, trauma, and grief. Every scene peels back a new layer from the incredibly cast of characters. There is no scene that is not dedicated to character development, and every scene propels the narrative to higher stakes and character depth. Full of subtle and admittedly not-so-subtle symbolism, many of our 21st century anxieties are depicted. Thought-provoking and moving, what may at first seem like gratuitous shock, or over-the-top characterization, is actually perfectly paced and only introduced when needed to both familiarize the audience with brutal reality and to bring us further into despair with our characters. The classic Aronofsky character study, critics will dislike this one for being bold enough to hold a mirror to society, even if it means portraying controversial subject matter. Audiences can dislike it if they take it on face value without wanting to take a deep dive into characterization, be it the ones on-screen or their own. There is much at work here and it may take a second watch for some to understand all the characters.

In regards to the accusations of "fatphobia", I would argue that the main character's weight is treated as secondary to the primary story of grief and despair, as a symptom and not the problem. The film has a few shocking moments, with most happening at the start of the film, only to get the audience accustomed with the physical state of the main character. I would also argue that if people accuse something of being fatphobic simply because they are disgusted by seeing fat people, then they themselves are the problematic ones.
