Using Samuel Hunter's source material quite faithfully Darren Aronofsky and Brendan Fraser were able to create cinematic magic with the screenplay adaption of The Whale. A tour de force in embodying pain and joy through the simple gesture of eye contact through moments of both dialogue and solo shots. A story encapsulated in empathy and surrounded in sorrow, Aronofsky is able to recreate the intimacy of stage play through the blocking and committing to focus of the character Charlie and the week we spend with him, his family, and his environment. I do believe I had some hangups with the way the daughter character Ellie played by Sadie Sink, was handled towards the end of the movie. Without spoiling, I don't think the emotional pendulum is off based giving the story and the character, I did feel the grim reality was almost whisked away, in lue of conveying a bit more explicitly the underlying themes that parallel not only Moby Dick but the mystery student's book review essay critiquing Herman Melville's acclaimed novel. In such a fashion, that leans pessimistic yet honest and is the catalyst for what Charlie's desire is for all those around him, especially after the rising action of the first portion of the film. Again, my critiques are simply me acknowledging I didn't give it a 5 but that doesn't mean The Whale isn't a beautiful work of art, with some sad but true messaging throughout it.

Acclaimed filmmaker Darren Aronofsky tells a ‘whale of a tale’ so to speak based on the stage play Brendan Fraser makes an incredible comeback after years being out of the spotlight He perfectly shines as Charlie, an overly obese man; a English literature professor that has become a recluse in his own home He never goes outside and spends so much of his time eating away and teaching online courses Charlie once had a wife and daughter but abandoned them after falling in love with one of his students He is alone and only taken care of by an on-call nurse Charlie’s daughter for 8 years then shows up venting her frustration against him but he sees this an opportunity to get to know her and have some closure until his inevitable passing Charlie’s also surrounded by people who have secrets from his nurse to his ex wife to a missionary that visits him frequently It’s all about the actors but Brendan Fraser really becomes this character; you really do feel for him that he is slowly fading away and all he wants is know that he has done one good thing in his entire life Sadie Sink who plays his daughter is utterly spectacular being this child acting out despite her not showing she’s capable of being okay There is a bit too much monologuing and it is confined to one space throughout Plus the pan and scan ratio is a bit odd but the purpose is to make the audience feel just as confined as this lead character Mainly the players and the emotions are what keep you invested People are incapable of not caring, all that matters is what you say, in a way we are all whales; doesn’t matter if we are skinny or fat it’s that we are still full of love, lies, hope, and promising potential to do good for people The music is very emotionally satisfying, the acting is top notch, and the ending really made me well up with tears Polarizing yes as are most of Aronofsky’s works but overall this is a story of a father searching for meaning and redemption to pass along Fraser’s performance will floor you even if you can predict the tragic outcome

It is honestly one of the best performances I've seen on film. As a noted prior film critic back during my college years, and current cinephile. I can tell you that Brendan Fraser's "Charlie" is nothing I've ever seen or experienced before. The performance is so emotionally taxing. If, you've dealt with depression, guilt, grief, pain, self harm. This performance will haunt you. Charlie is a very complex man, one thing to note is his optimism, empathy and love for those that share his space. 

Adding, the supporting characters held their own too. Ho Chung's "Liz" who portrays Charlie's caregiver/friend is immaculate she rightfully deserves supporting actress Oscar nod. Through her story you see someone that has suffered a huge loss, and she's caring for someone who's given up and she's perilous to stop their self destructive behavior. However all she wants is to make Charlie comfortable. Her performance is on the nose but extremely nuanced as well. If, you've loved someone that has essentially given up on life and also witnessed these same behaviors in someone else you'll feel her performance. It is devastating to witness two people you love essentially suffer the same fate. And, there's nothing you can do about it. 

Lastly, there's Sadie Sink's "Ellie" her performance is visceral. And, she'll surely be splitting the votes with Ho Chung. Her performance is harsh, unrelenting and punishing. She portrays Charlie's daughter, if you've ever felt abandoned by someone you loved, a parent you'll understand. She essentially is all what Charlie lives for however she never knew. But, as a kid it's not up to her to push for a relationship it was him, that should have fought for her. Despite his limited mobility and depression, him not being in her life affected her deeply, and he deserves her wrath. I've never been abandoned by a parent, however I have people in my life who have and I understand the pain that it causes, and scars that never heals.

Overall this movie is masterful and is a character/case study on our humanity and empathy. I've viewed some hot takes and read some articles where critics gave negative reviews and claimed the movie was "fatphobic". Those folks just want to be derisive and surly for the sake of being an other. If, your takeaway is that. You are lacking in emotional intelligence. 

This film's purpose is for the viewer at the end to feel as optimistic, as Charlie. And, if you can pick yourself up through despair and grab life by the reigns, you owe to yourself and those that love you to do so.

Characters were great, even the ones you were supposed to "hate". Brendan Fraser plays his role as Charlie perfectly- he's the man who, even when he's being confronted with something he doesn't agree with or dislikes, still keeps himself composed enough and never really raises his voice in anger at anyone. It's more realistic than many other movies in a similar ilk. I also applaud the movie for tackling an issue you don't really see outside of TLC's My 600lb Life and etc. Most overweight people are played off either as comedy or as highly confrontational about their weight with reality being most fat people know they're fat, admit they're fat, and yet are still very much real living and feeling people who are just as much deserving of a protagonist role in a story as the chiseled hunk or shapely femme fatale.

The biggest problem I had with the movie was the fact that much of the exposition is through dialog rather than flashbacks or actions. I understand that this is a modern trend in movies and that it saves on budget, but I would have enjoyed a few more instances of, say, showing the deceased partner or glimpses of Charlie's life prior to his binge eating.

All-in-all, as a fat guy myself I connected with this movie and hope to see more movies like it in the future.

what a fantastic bookend to Fraser's (almost) freshman effort "Gods and Monsters".  Certainly a tour de force for him.  One thing that I noticed critics complaining about is how 'stagey' the film is.  Well, it *was* a stage play.  Not the first time an adaptation for screen doesn't play as we think it should.  ( it should be noted that Hunter, the playwright, said in an intrview with NBC "Darren said on day one that we're a theater company, and we dug into it as you would dig into a text. He blocked it like you would block a play with the exception of like, we weren't playing everything to an audience."  So there you have it. 
I have to say that my main / only complaint was an aspect of Sadie Sink's performance.  And I don't mean to say her performance was bad in any way.  (although it was clear to me from the first minute that everyone in the cast could act their pants off - and no one was going to come close to Fraser, who pulled this off with a knowledgeable grace that perhaps no one else could).  Sink gave a fine performance.  What stuck with me after, though, was how, when she was raging (often) she many times resorted to the same ragin' spot.  A quote from W Magazine: 'To capture Ellie's pain, Sink and Aronofsky nerded out on acting fundamentals—experimenting with blocking, the character's way of moving through the apartment, and the different forms in which her anger manifested.'  I submit they didn't perhaps, 'nerd-out' enough.   Granted, when almost all the action is inside the living room of the apartment, options are limited.  And granted, this is a 20-year-old actress, climbing a veritable mountain of a role.  I just would have liked to have seen something *more* come out of the 'nerd out'.  As for what many folks have noted (which maybe should be called 'squeamish factor'), as Charlie says.....it's honest.  Too honest?  Like Charlie, too large for comfort?  I can't speak to that.  I can only say that it was a huge dose of honest humanity.  And that dose was, in the main, due to Mr. Fraser.  Welcome back, dude.

I want to start off this review by stating the obvious which is that Brendan Fraser is an incredible acting talent as Charlie. While he didn't actually gain all that weight to star in the film, his commitment to learning how to move in such a bulky and complex set of prosthetics his commendable. That isn't mentioning his engrossing portrayal of a man who has regrets and has fallen into a secluded life gorging himself to death in a dingy apartment. Yet despite all of his flaws Charlie wields an enormous empathy and recognition of positive attributes. This is apparent in his interactions with his students through the online course that he teaches and even more so in his relationship with his estranged daughter. Darren Aronofsky clearly spent a long time finding a lead that would work for the film and Brendan Fraser really REALLY works. 

        Speaking of Charlie's estranged daughter, Sadie Sink also brings her A game as Ellie in a portrayal of a daughter who his hurt by her father's mistakes and clearly wants nothing to do with him in the beginning of the movie. It is evident that her mother Mary (played by Samantha Morton) only sees Ellie's negative aspects but Charlie sees something more. When Mary shows Charlie how unflinchingly rude her daughter is online, the FIRST words out of Charlie's mouth are spoken in admiration of Ellie's honesty. Charlie knows that Ellie's outward behavior is indicative of a much deeper core that he wants to draw out of her, and it's so emotionally satisfying to watch. I know people will criticize the casting for grabbing at star power but I think the casting overall is really great. 

        The score is so menacing, yet ultimately triumphant, The story rides such an emotional wave that I forget it's all set in a dingy apartment. I somehow want to read Moby Dick now; I don't know what else to say about this movie except that more people should be going out to see this movie!

Spoilers sort of: I loved the premise, and it started strong- but there's nothing redeeming or interesting about the story. Main character had a bad thing happen in their life and became just an awful person. He uses money to guilt his child into spending time with him instead of actually becoming someone worth spending time with! Worse - his fake optimism that exists for anything other than his own life or responsibilities. The missionary character was ridiculous and made no sense, neither did his caregivers story- trying to make you feel for them but the writing sucked. Overall, this needed a couple rewrites before ever being made and it's a shame because Fraser's acting was good for the most part. I don't think this paints a very good picture for those suffering with the kind of pain shown here- if anything, it says you're only worth something if you hoard money and time your outreach to those who should be loved ones perfectly. Further- as someone far removed from evangelicalism after growing up in it- if you're going to take that topic head on maybe consult some people on what it's actually like to be scorned by a church community. This didn't represent those people well either, and maybe that was the saddest part.

THE WHALE is a film about addiction, loss, love, failure, success, life, death and everything in between. The filmmakers are not shaming anyone for eating themselves to 600 pounds. They're telling a story about how a trauma and heartbreak caused someone who struggles with food addiction to descend into the depths of addiction... and in the face of death, reckon with what it is to be a father, lover, friend and human being.

There have been countless films on addiction that involved alcohol and drugs. This one involves food. These are very very very real things that people use as coping mechanisms. And they can, and do, destroy peoples lives. Body Positivity and Fat Acceptance do not have to discount the quality of storytelling that's happening with The Whale, but unfortunately, that seems to be what's happening with critics right now. 

There wasn't a dry eye in the AMC theater I saw "The Whale" in this afternoon. Most of us stayed seated well past the credits, still stunned by the film and its performances. Employees had to ask us to leave so they could clean.

I recommend seeing this film. Highly recommend. And should you have moments where you're perturbed by what you're seeing, I recommend taking a deep, deep look at why you're feeling what you're feeling. Chances are, you're about to learn something about your own relationship with trauma and coping.
